awd_titl_txt: PFI:AIR - TT: Multifunctional Underwater Sealants with Long-Term Sustained Release Functionality
awd_abstract_narration:
This PFI: AIR Technology Translation project focuses on translating a new multifunctional moldable and adhesive material with small molecule controlled-release properties.  Two potential applications have been identified: one as an underwater sealant, good for emergency water leak repair, and one as a controlled-release device, capable of multiple-month release of active small molecules for disinfectants, herbicides, fragrances, pheromones or drugs.  When used as an underwater sealant, the new material has the unique features of immediately sticking when pressed to a wet surface (rather than requiring a dry surface or a significant setting time), and could stop leaks faster than competing products. When used for long-term sustained release, the material also: (1) adheres to diverse surface types; (2) can be molded to fit most shapes; and (3) requires no organic solvents or high temperatures during production (which reduces toxicity and prevents payload degradation). This unique combination of properties could make this sustained release material safer and more versatile than the leading competing products. This project will result in prototypes that demonstrate how the new material can be used for both applications, and in a comprehensive set of guidelines for appropriately tailoring the material's adhesion, stability and long-term release properties. 

This project will address several knowledge and technology gaps as it translates the new multifunctional material toward commercialization. To enable its successful use as an underwater sealant, the researchers will investigate: (1) how different modes of stress affect adhesive failure at various ionic strength, pH and temperature levels; (2) how rheological and adhesion properties evolve upon aging (and how these changes correlate to the structural rearrangements within the material); (3) how adhesion properties depend upon application method; and (4) how adhesion and rheological properties change upon drying. These analyses will both elucidate how and where the proposed material may be used as a sealant, and advance fundamental understanding of ionically crosslinked polyelectrolytes (from which the new material is formed). Further, to enable its commercial use as a long-term sustained release vehicle, this project will establish methods for optimizing this material to efficiently encapsulate small molecules (regardless of their affinity for the encapsulating polymer or their solubility), and will generate approaches for tuning their sustained release. By demonstrating how this ionic network can be tailored to deliver antimicrobial agents, herbicides and other actives over multiple months, this project will provide essential guidelines for the use of this material in commercial sustained-release applications. 

In addition, project personnel, including graduate and undergraduate students, will receive innovation and technology translation experiences through: (1) research and development; (2) completing a four-week (mini I-Corps type) course on customer discovery and product-market fit offered through UT's entrepreneurship/business incubator program; and (3) participating in meetings with potential industry partners, which will be conducted in partnership with UT's Technology Transfer Office.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Recently discovered materials with numerous potential household, industrial, and healthcare applications were systematically studied. The mixing of charged polymers (polyelectrolytes) with oppositely charged molecules in water generated unique materials with desirable properties. Specifically, novel materials formed spontaneously upon mixing of common commercial ingredients (polyallylamine and tripolyphosphate) in water have at least two distinct applications: first, as underwater adhesives/sealants; and second, as controlled-release systems capable of slowly releasing active small molecules (e.g., drugs, fragrances, disinfectants, or herbicides) over multiple months. To assess the translational potential of these materials, this project examined: (1) how they perform as adhesives under diverse conditions, including upon aging; and (2) their ability to encapsulate and slowly release different types of active small molecules, as well as approaches to tailoring their encapsulation and release performance. These tasks aimed to both advance the fundamental understanding of how these materials function and develop practical guidelines for their possible commercial use.

Building on our earlier studies that demonstrated the underwater adhesion of these materials to glass, polymethyl methacrylate, and Teflon, this project has shown these multifunctional materials to also adhere to metals (stainless steel and copper) and additional plastic substrates (including the difficult-to-bond polyethylene and polypropylene). Further, we have demonstrated that these underwater adhesives/sealants can work under a broad range of conditions, with little sensitivity to whether adhesion occurs under deionized, tap, lake, or sea water. An exception to this efficacy was when the polyallylamine-tripolyphosphate adhesive was used to adhere water-saturated wood (maple), which was softer than the other examined surfaces and, due to the prolonged soaking required to saturate it with water, coated with a microbial biofilm. The adhesion to this softer and biofouled substrate was much weaker than that to the other tested substrates and suggested the adhesive/sealant materials examined in this project to work best on hard, clean surfaces. Their (tensile) adhesion strength when they were pulled apart was significantly stronger than their (lap shear) sliding adhesion strength, which indicated these materials to adhere best in applications where the stress is applied perpendicular (rather than parallel) to the adhesion surface. Moreover, we have discovered that this bond strength can increase over time when the adhered surfaces are pressed together over several days and that these materials are quite stable (even without refrigeration) with their flow and adhesion properties persisting throughout 9-months of testing.

Besides advancing the understanding of these adhesion properties, we have shown that these materials can encapsulate a wide range of hydrophilic and hydrophobic small molecules (e.g., drugs, disinfectants, and herbicides). When the active payloads either bind to the polyallylamine or tripolyphosphate or are hydrophobic, they can be encapsulated in high amounts (exceeding 20% of the material's total weight). Once encapsulated, each of these molecules can be released over multiple months and, using a bactericide as a model payload, we have shown that this sustained release can produce a multiweek antibacterial effect. Yet, over timescales beyond one month, this antibacterial activity was fully lost. This eventual deactivation was attributed to the gradual drop in the bactericide release rate and indicated the bactericidal efficacy of the materials (though still highly sustained) to not be as durable as the underlying release process. To prevent -- or at least delay -- such deactivation (which is likely to also eventually occur in other sustained release applications), we developed a method of stimulating/reactivating the sustained release when it becomes too slow. Specifically, we have shown that release into water can be greatly accelerated when the material is periodically perforated or compressed. Such mechanical activation (which could potentially be electronically controlled) provides a pathway to overcoming challenges associated with insufficient release rates.

Collectively, this project's findings provide a fuller understanding of the flow, adhesion, and encapsulation/release properties of soft materials formed from polyallylamine-tripolyphosphate mixtures and, thus, generate essential guidelines for their practical use. Indeed, this adhesive technology has (through a license agreement) already been implemented in a commercial product. Besides its scientific and technological impacts, this project has contributed to student training and K-12 outreach. Four graduate and five undergraduate students were trained in polymer science, controlled release technologies and, in one graduate student's case, microbiology. Two of these graduate students also received training in customer discovery and entrepreneurship through UToledo's I-Corps Site Program and, through the NSF INTERN program, one of the graduate students received industrial R&D training at a leading chemical company. Finally, the project team introduced roughly 50 middle/high school students to polymer science through the EXCEL program, which the University of Toledo offers to Toledo Public Schools to engage girls and students of color in science, engineering, and technology.


Last Modified: 01/17/2022
Modified by: Yakov Lapitsky
